statement.tex: %text Let $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{4}{2}$, $\ora{b}=\vector{3}{-2}{7}$ and $\ora{c}=\vector{2}{-1}{4}$. Find a vector $\ora{d}$ which is perpendicular to both $\ora{a}$ and $\ora{b}$ and $\ora{c}\cdot \ora{d}=18$. %

step.context: %text If vector $\ora{d}=\vector{d_1}{d_2}{d_3}$ is perpendicular to $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{3}{2}$ and $\ora{b}=\vector{3}{-2}{7}$, can we say the following about $d_1$, $d_2$ and $d_3$? %
step.reason: %text When two vectors are perpendicular their dot product is zero. Therefore, % \begin{align} &\ora{a}\cdot \ora{d}=0 \\ \implies &\left(\vector{1}{3}{2}\right)\cdot \left(\vector{d_1}{d_2}{d_3}\right)=0 \\ \implies & d_1+3d_2+2d_3= 0 \end{align} \\ %text Similarly, $\ora{b}\cdot \ora{d}=0$ therefore, % \qquad 3d_1-2d_2+7d_3 = 0.

step.context: %text If $\ora{c}=\vector{2}{-1}{4}$, $\ora{d}=\vector{d_1}{d_2}{d_3}$ and $\ora{c}\cdot\ora{d}=18$, what can we deduce from this about $d_1$, $d_2$ and $d_3$? %
%text Solve for $\ora{d}$ if $\ora{d}=\vector{d_1}{d_2}{d_3}$ and if $d_1+3d_2+2d_3=0$, $3d_1-2d_2+7d_3=0$ and $2 d_1-d_2+4d_3 =18$. %
step.reason: \begin{align} d_1+3d_2+2d_3 &= 0 \\ 3d_1-2d_2+7d_3 &= 0 \\ 2 d_1-d_2+4d_3 &=18 \end{align} \\ %text We have three equations and three unknowns. On systematically eliminating them one by one, we get $d_1=64$, $d_2=-2$ and $d_3=-28$. % \therefore \ora{d}=\vector{64}{-2}{-28}
